"They will be open for feedback from Oct. 9 to Nov. 8, 2024",  maybe regulated after some time, but nice to hear that
Do you have a source on this? Curious where you got the Nov 8 date from.

Policy goes into effect November 8.

China’s policies on solar production are moving closer to implementation, as both the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT) and the National Energy Administration (NEA) have confirmed draft regulations that focus on controlling overcapacity, encouraging higher efficiency, and improving environmental standards within the photovoltaic (PV) manufacturing sector.

For PV manufacturing, the MIIT’s new guidelines target reducing overcapacity by enforcing strict efficiency benchmarks and minimum capital requirements for new projects, aiming to drive more responsible and sustainable growth. Companies that cannot meet these requirements might face shutdowns, likely consolidating the industry and enhancing product quality ￼ ￼.

The NEA has also proposed changes in the distributed solar market, introducing new categories and limiting grid access options for large-scale commercial and industrial (C&I) solar projects. The draft mandates unique identification codes for projects and introduces a green certificate system that financially rewards clean energy. These policies, open for public feedback until November 8, suggest a clear intent from the Chinese government to curb the rapid, unchecked expansion of solar production, particularly in response to market oversupply and price drops over recent years ￼ ￼.

The shift in policy is designed to prevent market disruption from overcapacity while promoting sustainable industry growth in China, though it could slow immediate expansion in certain sectors.

Canadian Solar’s CSI Solar Co. reported a third-quarter operating revenue of 12.22 billion yuan and a net profit of 0.72 billion yuan, marking an 8.3% increase from the previous quarter. The company continues to leverage its strong position in utility-scale energy storage and advanced manufacturing, with North American shipments accounting for over 30% of its module sales. Despite some year-over-year declines, Canadian Solar maintains a positive cash flow and is committed to technological innovation with a significant number of patents.

Take note of advanced manufacturing and patents. The key IMO.

The biggest fear factor for this stock comes down to a saturated Solar market, in which investors buy USA solar stocks (look, FSLR, ENPH, RUN). The other issue is interest rates are not at a level investors view as positive. Finally, the shorts are winning this battle (hedge fund money). At the end of day, there are just better stocks to invest in. The only wild card will be if China actually announces concrete stimulus. But they will most likely wait 30 days until the USA election occurs. Last word, I am a buyer in this range. I've owned this stock for 15 years. It has done these cycles of long term down, short term ups. Good luck to the CSIQ investors.

Canadian solar has just raised $200 million by issuing convertible notes with PAG, a leading investment firm in Asia Pacific. These notes carry a 6% annual interest rate and can be converted into shares later, potentially leading to a 14.2% dilution of the current share base if fully converted.However, this dilution would only make financial sense for PAG if the share price grows to $18.20, which is 23.4% above the current price of $14.75. This means that, even with potential dilution, we could still see a net gain of 9.2%: Net Gain = 23.4% (Price Appreciation) - 14.2% (Dilution) = 9.2% ProfitAdditionally, this action reflects confidence from a major Asia Pacific investment firm that Canadian Solar's shares are likely to appreciate to at least $18.20, reinforcing the for future growth—definitely a positive sign.The market is reacting negatively in the premarket, likely not fully understanding the whole picture. This presents a potential opportunity for us to capitalize on the situation.There is also earnings report this Thursday. Great opportunities to buy before the interest rate cut in September.
